Summary: The proposal introduces an adaptive model-based RL framework to improve sample efficiency by dynamically balancing model-free and model-based updates based on uncertainty and learning progress. It includes uncertainty-calibrated model learning, dynamic policy-update weighting, and stabilized long-horizon rollouts. The experiment plan covers validation, ablation studies, and real-world deployment.
Strengths: Clear and well-motivated problem statement grounded in prior work.
Innovative hypothesis with a novel dynamic weighting mechanism.
Technically sound proposed method leveraging ensemble models and uncertainty estimation.
Comprehensive experiment plan including validation, ablation studies, and real-world deployment.
Weaknesses: Lacks detailed discussion on computational overhead of ensemble models.
Scalability of dynamic weighting mechanism to high-dimensional spaces is not thoroughly explored.
Potential risks in real-world deployment (e.g., sim-to-real gaps) are not deeply analyzed.
Questions: How will the computational overhead of the ensemble models be managed in high-dimensional spaces?
What are the fallback mechanisms if the dynamic weighting fails to converge?
How will the method handle non-stationary environments where the dynamics model may drift?
What specific regularization techniques will be used to prevent overfitting in the ensemble models?
Limitations: Computational cost of ensemble models may limit scalability.
Dynamic weighting mechanism may introduce additional hyperparameters that require tuning.
Real-world deployment may face challenges due to sim-to-real gaps.
